*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, individuals have a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing injury or damage to others.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others and applies that principle to the defendant homeowner. Although the case then focuses on a more specific firearm-storage duty, its articulation of the general duty rule directly supports the cited proposition about the duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to secure any items placed near the shared driveway to avoid foreseeable risks of harm, including to Plaintiff’s vehicle.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The case concerns a residential landlord’s duty as a landowner to remedy an open and obvious danger the landlord created and maintained (a trampoline set directly beside a shallow pool), not a duty to secure items near a shared driveway or to prevent damage to a vehicle. The holding is about the scope of a premises-liability duty to remedy open and obvious conditions where the landowner can anticipate entrants will encounter the risk, and does not address anything about driveways, vehicles, or a duty to secure objects in that context. Using this case for that specific driveway/vehicle-duty proposition would be inaccurate.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… However, ‘[l]andowners are relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers on their premises…’ A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ … Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool… for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool.”

*Walker v. Town of Franklin*, 416 Mass..proposition: Plaintiff’s economic injuries, including repair costs and rental car expenses, were a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s breach of duty.

*Raunela v. Hertz Corp.*, 361 Mass. 341,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct reflects a failure to adhere to standards of reasonable care under the circumstances, as required under Massachusetts negligence law.
*Raunela v. Hertz Corp.*, 361 Mass. 341,.support_reasoning: The opinion applies ordinary Massachusetts negligence principles, but it does not articulate or discuss a general standard that the defendant must adhere to "standards of reasonable care under the circumstances." Instead, it focuses on whether there was sufficient evidence of the truck driver’s negligence to warrant jury consideration and procedural issues about verdicts and damages. The case thus illustrates a factual application of negligence law rather than clearly stating or analyzing the general duty-of-reasonable-care standard described in the proposition.
*Raunela v. Hertz Corp.*, 361 Mass. 341,.relevant_excerpt: On the defendants’ exceptions to the denial of their motion for directed verdicts the test is whether “anywhere in the evidence, from whatever source derived, any combination of circumstances could be found from which a reasonable inference could be drawn in favor of the plaintiff.” ... We hold that such a combination of circumstances could be found in the evidence and that the case was therefore properly submitted to the jury for decision.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to the Massachusetts General Laws (G.L. c. 212, § 3) because the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Hampden County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the incident giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Springfield, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Prejudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7 1.proposition: Costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261, § 1;
